title: Namibia: Livestock Industry None the Wiser After SA Meeting
text:
South Africa: Govt in Bid to Educate Millions Without Grade 9 
The fresh round of talks follows after a recent notice in the SA Government Gazette, which introduced a consultation process about the re-introduction of strict animal health regulations for imports from South Africa. 
Namibia has objected to this on the highest level after such drastic requirements was implemented overnight by South Africa, bringing the Namibian export industry worth some N$2.4 billion per annum to its knees in 2014. 
The first round of brainstorming took place under the auspices of the Meat Board of Namibia during the quarterly industry meeting of the National Animal Health Forum and the National Livestock Marketing Committees. The South African directorate of animal health gave notice in early April of the new consultation process about the introduction of new animal health regulations regarding imports from other countries. 
Namibia supplies some 160 000 weaners per annum to the South African market as part of the countries billion dollar export industry. 
In August 2014 the stringent new regulations were temporarily lifted in order for stakeholders to give inputs after the devastating effect of these regulations were observed by South African authorities. 
This opportunity urged Namibian authorities to compile all necessary documents and have Namibia declared free of certain animal diseases. 
These files to declare Namibia free from diseases like "Peste de Petit Ruminantes" (PPR) and Boviene Spongforme Ensefalopatie (BSE) were handed over by the Namibian Directorate of Veterinary Services (DVS) to the International Animal Health Organisation (OIE) for approval.It was also decided certain farms would be declared free from diseases like tuberculosis and brucellose in order for livestock to be exported from these farms to South Africa. 
The Meat Board is busy with these processes in coordination with DVS. 
The Livestock Marketing Committee reiterated its quest for finding alternative export markets for goats and weaners in other neighbouring countries. 
The possibility also exists Namibian weaners could be rounded off in unused quarantine camps in the area north of the Veterinary Corridor Fence and that feedlots could be erected in such areas while fodder could be supplied. Namibia
